thread.title: North Platte National Weather Service issues winter weather outlook, warns of ice jam hazards
thread.title_full: North Platte National Weather Service issues winter weather outlook, warns of ice jam hazards

author: @knopnews2
title: North Platte National Weather Service issues winter weather outlook, warns of ice jam hazards
text:
Submit Photos and Videos NextGen TV Zeam - News Streams Service Directory Birthday Club Circle Country Gray DC Bureau InvestigateTV Watching Your Wallet PowerNation Digital Marketing North Platte National Weather Service issues winter weather outlook, warns of ice jam hazards Meteorologists are closely monitoring conditions that could lead to hazardous winter storms, along with an elevated risk for ice jams along rivers and streams. By Justin Craft Published: Dec. 12, 2024 at 8:57 AM CST Email This Link
Share on Facebook
Share on X (formerly Twitter)
Share on Pinterest
Share on LinkedIn
NORTH PLATTE, Neb. (KNOP) - The National Weather Service has released its preliminary winter weather outlook, warning residents of potential hazards as the colder months approach.
Meteorologists are closely monitoring conditions that could lead to hazardous winter storms, along with an elevated risk for ice jams along rivers and streams.
“Ice jamming occurs quite frequently but thankfully the jams are usually not significant, said NWS Meteorologist Shawn Jacobs. “We don’t suggest people go anywhere near the river when there is ice forming or jamming up but they tend to be more of a nuisance for people with property along the river.”
The NWS urges people to remember safety first.
“It’s a great reminder to stay off the ice on the rivers and it’s been warmer than normal and that ice and water underneath causes dangerous conditions,” said Jacobs. “So if the river is jamming up just use caution and stay away.”
Lastly, people should stay vigilant and ready for potential emergencies.
“We want everybody to be prepared and have a plan because it’s a question of when winter storms will come here in Nebraska and people living in town and the farmers and ranchers who live in rural areas make sure to have a plan and be prepared,” said Jacobs.
